awd_titl_txt: The Second International Conference on Computational Methods and Applications in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports participation in the Second International Conference on Computational Methods and Applications in Engineering held at Mississippi State University on May 7-9, 2020.  With the rapid development of high-performance computing and its applications, robust mathematical models and their efficient computational algorithms and simulations have emerged as an essential analysis tool in science and engineering. In this regard, various professional scientific/engineering societies host cross-disciplinary conferences and meetings in related areas. However, a truly multidisciplinary conference with a focused theme, which provides a forum for mathematical scientists and engineers to share their research, is needed in the field of computational mathematics, sciences, and engineering. Moreover, this effort should reach researchers from many different countries. For this purpose, an interdisciplinary conference was successfully organized in 2018 by Mississippi State University and Universitatea Politehnica Timisoara, Romania. The main objective of this project is to continue to carry the same theme and tradition of the first conference and to host “The Second International Conference on Computational Methods and Applications in Engineering” on the campus of Mississippi State University. A mission of the conference is to further expand the established collaboration between the organizing institutions and to provide a joint forum where computational scientists and engineers from all over the world exchange research ideas in related fields. 

The conference offers five plenary lectures to be given by experts. The conference will also feature around 50 mini-symposium talks and 80 contributed papers. The mini-symposium topics include: 1) Recent Developments in Non-conforming Finite Element Methods, 2) Recent Advances in Time-Integration of Partial Differential Equations (PDEs), 3) Instability, Transition and Turbulence in Fluids: from Fundamentals to Applications, 4) Constitutive Modeling of Engineering Materials and Computational Simulations, 5) Lower Length Scale Methods in Machine Learning, 6) Recent Advances in Numerical PDEs: Fast Algorithms and Applications, 7) Numerical Methods and Models for High-Performance Computational Fluid Dynamics, and 8) Numerical Methods for Optimization Problems with PDE Constraints. Proceedings of the conference will be published as refereed manuscripts in a special issue of the Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics. The conference will provide graduate students and early career researchers with an opportunity to present their work, meet other researchers and educators, and learn of recent developments in the field of computational methods and engineering applications.  More details are available on the conference web site https://www.iccmae2020.math.msstate.edu/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to organize a truly multidisciplinary conference entitled “The Second International Conference on Computational Methods and Applications in Engineering” which provides a forum for mathematicians, scientists, and engineers to share their research in the area of computational sciences and engineering along with their applications to real world problems.  The primary objective of the conference was to further expand the established collaboration between organizing institutions, Mississippi State University and Universitatea Politehnica Timisoara, Romania, and offer researchers in the USA and Europe a place to exchange research and develop ideas in related fields. Another goal of the conference was to provide graduate students and recent Ph.D.s an opportunity to present their work, to meet future collaborators, and to learn of recent developments in the proposed interdisciplinary field.

The conference was held on May 7-8, 2022 in a hybrid format (virtual and in-person) at Mississippi State University. Five plenary lectures were presented by the following speakers:

Liliana Borcea - University of Michigan, “Waveform Inversion via Reduced Order Modeling”

Ludovic Dan Lemle - University Politehnica Timisoara, Romania, “On the Uniqueness of the Fokker-Planck-Kolmogorov Equation Associated with Schrödinger’s operators”

Julie C Mitchell - Oak Ridge National Laboratory, “Machine Learning Models for Biophysics”

Shahram Rahimi - Mississippi State University, “Foresight: A Game-Theory Based System with Reinforcement-Learning for Predictive Analytics”  

Radu Vasiu - University Politehnica Timisoara, Romania, “Actual Challenges for International Higher Education, Research and Innovation as part of the Digital Transition Policies”

In addition, ten mini-symposium sessions containing 49 invited talks were given. The  mini-symposium consisted of five sessions in computational mathematics and four sessions in computational engineering, and 1 session in data science. There were also a total of 48 contributed talks given at the conference. A total of 128 participants (80 in-person and 48 virtual) registered for the conference representing seven different countries including Austria, Canada, Italy, Romania, Switzerland, United Kingdom, and USA. 

One of the main features of the conference was the involvement of many young researchers (especially underrepresented minorities) in science and engineering, including graduate students, post-doctorate associates, and junior faculty. A total of 18 graduate students and recent Ph.D.s from outside the Mississippi State University were supported by the NSF to participate and present their research at the conference. Using our internal grant, we also supported registration fees of 23 Mississippi State graduate students/recent Ph.D.s. Among these 41 young researchers, 9 were women and 6 were minority students/recent Ph.D.s. 

A refereed conference proceedings were published as a special issue of the Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics (JCAM) by Elsevier, see https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/journal-of-computational-and-applied-mathematics/special-issue/10T5NFTSF0L
